newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Sen. Specter has benign brain tumor removed.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Sen. Specter has benign brain tumor removed.

text.p: Republican Sen. Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania underwent outpatient treatment Friday to remove a benign brain tumour and his doctor said the lawmaker's prognosis was highly favourable.

"We're very optimistic about the outcome ... The success rate for this procedure is 98 percent," Dr. L. Dade Lunsford, chief of neurosurgery at Presbyterian University Hospital, told a news conference with Specter following the treatment.
Said Specter: "I feel fine. I had a good lunch. They served me a big piece of cake, that's what this day has been, a piece of cake."

Specter, 66, underwent a "Gamma Knife" radiation treatment to remove a small benign tumour that apparently resulted from the growth of tiny cells left from an operation Specter underwent in 1993 to remove a larger benign tumour.

He entered the hospital Friday morning and planned to leave later in the day. He underwent surgery in June 1993 to remove a benign tumour and a brain scan this year showed a small tumour had grown on the outer edge of the left, frontal brain between the brain and the skull.

The "Gamma Knife" procedure was developed in Sweden in 1967 and has been in use at the University of Pittsburgh since 1987. It focuses high-powered rays on a tumour, cutting off blood supply and causing it to shrivel up.
Specter was an early entry in the campaign for the 1996 Republican presidential nomination but withdrew early in the race.
